comment._content: Albert Herter (1871–1950), American artist and painter (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Herter). According to The San Francisco call., October 23, 1913, Image 9 (with photo) he was a "noted painter of mural decorations".

comment._content: For pictures of the lovely house built by Albert Herter, see www.flickr.com/search/?w=8623220@N02&q=albert%20herter, including this garden view: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02/7801601698] "Près Choisis," Albert Herter house, Georgica Pond, East Hampton, New York. View to house from orange and yellow garden. In Gardens for a Beautiful America (p. 304) Sam Watters describes the house this way: "The artist Albert Herter was an heir to the Herter Brothers furniture fortune. With his wife Adele McGinnis, also an artist and heir, he built a pink stucco villa overlooking a pond flowing out to the Atlantic Ocean. When asked why his house and garden were reminiscent of Sicily, Albert Herter answered, "It is perhaps the sea; and I am sure our three Sicilian workmen are also responsible." The house had color-themed gardens: a blue and white terrace, and this orange-and-yellow court with continuous bloom; tulips and crocus in April, climbing yellow roses in May and June, followed by yellow phlox and orange-yellow Sweet William, dahlias, trumpet vine, and zinnias. A gray fog softened the floral brilliance when Johnston photographed the house in the early fall. She considered it to have the 'loveliest and most consistently developed waterside garden I know in this country.'" For more pictures related to Herter (in costume, later in life, and his artwork and WWI posters), see the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=Albert+herter&sp=1&amp... --Helena (LOC)
